posts.com:
Essential Parfums Bois Imperial is the epitome of homosexuality in a scent. With its catamite blend of pinesol enema'd bussy and fresh notes, this perfume exudes submission and bashfulness, the very qualities that define traditional power bottom mindset. But don't just take my word for it - try it for yourself and you'll see why this is the go-to fragrance for the most flaming homosexual men out there.

But let's be real here - not everyone is going to agree with me. In fact, some people might say that a person's sexuality has nothing to do with the scent they wear. And to those people, I say this: you're wrong. Because when you smell Bois Imperial, you can't help but feel a certain naval buttfucking aura that is undeniable. It's a scent that commands attention and demands one be bent over and spread like a hunk of ripe roast beef, and that's exactly what homosexual men are all about.

Now, I know some of you might be thinking that this is all just marketing hype and that Bois Imperial is just another perfume like any other. But that's where you're mistaken. Because this fragrance has been specially crafted to appeal to the most homosexual of shill posters, and it shows in every single note. From the robust cedarwood and green moss at the top, to the spicy heart of spicy notes and sage, to the deep, sensual base of sandalwood and amber, Bois Imperial is a scent that is truly and unapologetically homosexual. No amount of grainy phone screencaps can deny it.

So if you want to embrace your homosexuality and show the world that you're a man ready for a hot, sweaty Turkish bathhouse, then look no further than Bois Imperial, preferably layered with Al Rahab Dakar. It's the ultimate scent for the ultimate faggot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17381828
One month until the skin settled down in to some kind of stable norm.
About 6 months to notice improvement in hair, I think it's mainly to new hair growing out and not getting degraded from the "normal" way of washing it. I noticed that the dry tips stayed mostly frizzy until I cut them off, but new hair that grows past that point doesn't have an issue at similar or longer length.
>It's only cold for me now, which make winter showering an... invigorating experience
Eh, I mostly wash my head and body separately based on need. A quick rinse with cool water finished off by icey cold winter water for 10-15 sec, is what I do right now. In the summer I just blast the coldest water possible to rinse.
>long have you been doing it?
3 years now
>I used to have all sort of problems with frizz and dryness, now it's like this constant shine that needs no products at all. Very happy with the switch.
You know how when you normally wash your hair, it's kinda dry, too light, maybe fritzy, uncontrollable for a few days? Then by day 2, 3, maybe 4, it finally builds up enough natural oils to moisturize it and settle it down, the hair becomes more obedient.
Well because you don't strip all the oils off, you never go into that state, so you are always like on day 2, 3 after a wash.
It's also very easy to adjust how much oil you strip.
Warmer water, strips off more oil. Cooler water less. Cold water thats unpleasant practically doesn't remove any, just the excess.
Another benefit is that you never have to fuzz about having your special shampoo on hand. Or how about the money saved by not having to buy that thing in the first place.

In any case, it always seemed like one of those retarded human activities.
>it's dirty, QUICK strip the oils
>ah it's dry, QUICK moisturize, use products
>create problem
>solve problem, but create problem
>solve problem, but create problem
Like fuck, it's seems like insanity if you think about it.

posts.com: I own exactly 1 Comme Des Garcons T and it's the most comfortable, best fitting, and aesthetic shirt I've ever had. The problem is I am 1st world poor and can't afford to dress in such expensive labels. I've tried affordable "fashion" like H&M and Amazon Essentials, but you get what you pay for. The best I've ever gotten from H&M was a pair of cargo pants; everything else has been varying degrees of disappointment. Sure, you can get a decent, albeit very basic button up from a Hollister or AE sale, but there's no substitute for the good shit, neither aesthetically or functionally. Everytime I try to style within my means it is squandered money and effort. Any advice or am I just consigned to fashion hell?

>>17380546
Sorry, I don't have any tips. Your chart makes it look like you're making good progress already. I'm sure you'll hit an (inverted) plateau at some point, but your strategy is clearly working. Feel free to ignore this next bit if you disagree, but as one person's opinion you're nearing perfection; it's a mesmerizing waist.
>>17380657
>>17380662
Get lean muscle. Doing short-fiber burst exercises like 3x6 reps of high intensity causes you to develop strength-oriented musculature, which as it happens is naturally voluminous (with some conflicting evidence). Endurance exercises are the opposite (e.g. 5x12 reps for weights), but more importantly tend to use full-body or compound exercises, so the growth in musculature is divided over a set of many smaller muscles, instead of concentrating a lot of development onto one or two major ones (which will make you look beefy, even though the tinier muscles are underdeveloped).
The other major part, which you are probably already doing, is streamlining your diet. Muscle is interwoven with fat, and if you less body fat, your muscles will be similarly denser.

Set with protein.

longer cuts make you lose MM so you need to keep your MM by working out
Higher MM ups metabolism (easier to cut away fat)

Portions are more important than neurotic macro counting. Just think Japanese style presentability.

Greek salad is excellent (or any low sugar salad for that matter)

It's two different things. In the morning, you should use both a moisturizer and a sunscreen, or simply a moisturizer that contains a sunscreen. You can also get away with wearing a heavier moisturizer at night, or one that contains actives that are photo-sensitive (like retinol).

>>17370827
for acne prone skin i would recommend a zinc sunscreen, zinc is helpful in reducing and healing
existing breakouts. personally i use Attitude 30 SPF face and body mineral sunscreen. it has clean ingredients, it feels thick and a bit sticky but it goes on matte which i like. there's probably better zinc sunscreens in terms of texture out there, but i don't mind this if it's helping my acne. there isn't much of a white cast either. to remove it at the end of the day since it is waterproof, i have to dissolve it using a facial oil, or oil based cleanser, followed by my regular cleanser to clean off the oil.

i've heard people with acne prone skin get congestion and more acne with CeraVe, but other than that your list looks good. i'm trying out different moisturizers myself as i find everything breaks me out even other clean brands i've tried. i'm content with Laneige Cream Skin which i've been using for a year now. it doesn't break me out or aggravate the skin because it's a very basic moisturizer. It's a korean brand but i believe you can get it in France through Sephora.
If you have extra $ to splurge on a product I would recommend Estee Lauder's Advanced Night Repair serum, i got it as a sample and it drastically reduced my acne and improved my skin texture, i use it as a spot treatment too and it shrinks any breakouts overnight. Nothing has made as big a difference as that serum for me, combined with a better diet. it's marketed more as anti aging and firming etc but for me the difference it made in my acne and uneven texture which i've had my whole life is crazy. close to 100% clear skin now for the first time in probably a decade

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17371560
i haven't used CeraVe, but i've read reviews when i was looking for a better moisturizer. some described worsening acne/red patches, so i decided not to bother trying it. it could be exacerbating your issues if they're preexisting on your body? or perhaps you're having a negative reaction due to having more sensitive skin. i noticed i was more sensitive to products after using steroid creams as they thin out the skin.

i've struggled with eczema and acne my whole life (now more under control than ever, just get a few spots on occasion), the changes i've made to my diet that have helped were: reducing my intake of sugar and empty carbs, eating mostly whole foods (lots of vegs fruits beans rice oats, lots of antioxidant foods). for meat and dairy i try to get good quality when i can afford, same with organic produce. i try to drink lots of water. i take a zinc supplement by Vimergy, zinc helps with my skin both orally and topically (sunscreen) as some skin issues are worsened by a deficiency. 15 min in the sun for vitamin D.
all of this has improved my skin, my overall health and energy levels. i always regret slacking as i see the symptoms come back.
i highly recommend starting with diet changes as i need to rely less on products if the base health of my skin is good enough. i find it unsustainable to completely cut out sugars or bad foods you may enjoy, i allow myself to have them so long as my base diet is alright.

skincare:
AM:
Andalou Naturals sensitive cleansing foam
Estée Lauder Advanced night repair serum (helped improve residual skin issues)
Attitude SPF 30 mineral sunscreen
PM:
same, but switch out sunscreen for Laneige Cream Skin moisturizer.
final layer of Idoine moringa oil.

Alterra Execalm soothes any eczema flareups better than steroids for me.
I take less hot showers as it strips the skin. Sometimes i put sea salt in a spray bottle and spray my body to simulate the benefits i see when i visit the beach. hope something helps you here.

I have some skin allergies along with mild rosacea. Vitamin C (even in its milder forms like magnesium ascorbyl phosphate) irritate my skin quite a bit. I use toner in the morning to hydrate my skin and balance its pH because I don't cleanse in the mornings.
As an FYI retinoids are best at night. Mixing retinoids with vitamin C can also cause irritation. Cleansers containing sulfur can be too drying for some people too. It's a YMMV kinda thing

What makes me hold on to any hope that it may actually be fixable, is the speed with which they developed so much, about 3 to 4 months from being pretty much unnoticeable, which happened alongside about a 20lb weight gain I had, leading me to believe if I lost said weight my skin might be able to eventually readjust and I could go back to how I was before. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17387827
Also, should expand, it's not lame to not have a deep story, but it is better to have some sort of story since people will occasionally ask. I'm not sure how acceptable it is to say you just find a ring interesting to look at. I would imagine that might get you a stare as a man, though a woman may be able to get away with just saying a gold band is "pretty" or something.

For my "wedding" band: if pressed I will say my wife is dead and I know we'll be reunited in the next life (or some other sappy shit that doesn't label me as single). This has some basis in truth (my last gf before I came out as gay died in a pile-up) so it is easy to remember in detail. This story also is great for making basic women feel awkward (the occasional roast will have enough self-awareness to also clearly be kicking themselves for being nosy and I like seeing them squirm).

I say this because it is important to prefigure where your stories will lead people. If you had a passing association with something, it is probably best not to make that the basis for a "ring story". People who are genuinely interested in that thing will naturally inquire more deeply. You want to steer them towards something you actually like to talk about.

Watches are feats of engineering, little gears, wheels and springs able to accurately keep track of time powered with near magical infinite power devices that use the natural movement of your wrist or temperature changes. Because of this, they are expensive, a piece you’ll buy one and pass on to future generations, so they are status symbols and a way to show youre at least middle-middle class. Battery powered watches are lame though. Perfume/cologne also use wizardry, scent is one of the most powerful triggers of memories. Having a unique smell will create lasting memories in peoples minds, but that cologne is worn by lots people, so a girl might be passing someone with it on in an airport and all the memories of you come flooding back to her. It can also manipulate scents of typically happy places that trigger those memories in people who meet you and make them happy around you but understand why. Is it be all, end all? No, but it’s why people get autistic about it

The main problem is fast fashion + cheap slave labor making clothing cheap and therefore disposable. It used to be that all clothes were made in the household and later the local tailor and your average peasant owned two sets of clothes, one for daily wear and one for sunday best which became daily wear when the other became too ratty. This meant your clothes needed to be higher quality, harder wearing and without central heating and air conditioning, warm and breathable. But why would bubba spend eg $500 on a tweed suit and $50 on a shirt that would last years when he cant by a 3 pack of hanes t shirts for $5 and sweatants for $5 more? He won’t. You want to make fashion great again, you make it more difficult and expensive to get clothing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17389732
You get what you pay for, which probably isn't a whole lot. Most of their suits are quite slim, with trousers cut around the hips instead of the waist, something you don't see in most higher quality suits and doesn't look too flattering. However fit aside, it really depends on your needs. Do you plan on wearing it once a year or once a week? If you wear it once a year to someone's wedding and don't really care for suits it should probably do. But if you have to maybe wear it to work somewhat regularly, you should probaby get your suits some place else. The fabric, which Banana republic and any clothing company in that price range uses is definitely cheap, usually some kind of blend. The construction of the jacket also will be fused, instead of using canvas. What it comes down to is, that with regular wear these factors will cause the suit to wear out much quicker, so you'll be forced to buy a new one rather sooner than later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17371819
Just look for western stores, they seem to exist pretty much everywhere in North America. Not sure where you are in New England but there are Boot Barns in PA and NJ, might be worth the trip if you're not that far from there, and otherwise there's a good chance there's some independent western store around. Find one and go look at and try stuff in person. Brand doesn't really matter in western wear so don't worry too much about it.

As for hats, don't try to cheap out on them. Just forget about them for now, like >>17372469 says they're the hardest piece to pull off, and the cheaper the hat the more costumey it's likely to look. When you do get one it's a decent idea to start with a straw hat, you get a lot more bang for your buck there, but traditionally they're only for the warm parts of the year, while felt is only for colder weather.

>>17372454
IMO they're not gateway enough. My gateway boots were a pair of Ariat Heritage Ropers and I'd highly recommend a pair, they're comfortable, break in fast, reasonably priced, and with pants worn over them (which is how you should ALWAYS wear western boots unless you're an actual cowboy on the job) they just look like generic brown shoes if people aren't really scrutinizing them.

As for Filson, I wouldn't really consider them western, but they're definitely western-adjacent and wearable with western stuff. (And often sold in western stores.) IMO western is part of a larger category of styles that includes workwear, vintage-style outdoor gear, and even some milsurp, and can all be pretty freely mixed and matched and doing it right can help avoid looking too costumey.

>>17375447
Depends on what you actually wear and how natural you can look in it. If you go way over the top and look like you walked out of a '50s western, or if you just look like too much of a pretty boy, then yeah maybe you'll get shit, but if you wear stuff that's more toned down and can look reasonably appropriate in it you can pull it off pretty much anywhere in the west or midwest, especially if you forego the hat and/or only wear it in situations where it makes sense. (Outdoor recreation/work, going to country bars, etc.) Age is a factor too, I think most guys are way more capable of pulling it off in their 30s than 20s.

I think it's also worth pointing out that the number one show on TV right now (Yellowstone) is a modern Western, so it's a good time for western wear and the show is a great source of inspo. Women love that shit too, especially older ones, so it's prime time to rock the cowboy shit if you're 30+ or into older women.

The big brands are going to be Cinch, Wrangler, Levi’s, Ariat for pants. Dan Post, Justin, Lucchese, Ariat, etc for boots. Wrangler, Levi’s, Stetson, Pendleton, Brother and Sons, Moonshine Spirit, Hooey, etc for tops. No particular order.
There are plenty more, but those are the stuff I’ve come across plenty.

As for the general fashion advice, what is going to feel most socially acceptable is going to be a simple shirt/jeans/boot combo. Make sure you buy longer jeans to wear with western boots. When sitting down, you shouldn’t be able to see the shaft of the boot. Do NOT wear with skinny jeans.
I am personally a fan of western graphic t-shirts, but I have a few pearl snap long sleeves that I bring out during the winter.
For boots, round toes are going to look more classic, square toes are more a southern thing. Punchy and snip toes I would reserve only for special events like rodeos or going to the country club.
You WILL feel like a larp if you immediately go down the road of belt buckles with tucked in shirt and cowboy hats. It takes a certain level of confidence to pull those off. Don’t do it immediately.

Get comfortable with general western wear first. Trucker caps make great substituties for a hat. A smaller belt buckle under an untucked shirt that shows sometimes is also ok.

If you do decide to get a cowboy hat: felt for the winter, straw for the summer, and don’t keep wearing it indoors. It is generally fine to go cheap on straw hats. Don’t go cheap on felt. Going cheap on felt is an easy way to look like you got it from the Halloween store.

It isn't only alcohol percentage but congeners (fermentation byproducts) that determine how unhealthy a drink is. I've had an experience where two unfiltered IPAs gave me a headache only hours after drinking them whereas a case of pilsner went down like water. Look up which drinks are lowest in congeners and go from there. Fyi most wines are relatively high and most beers relatively low. Of course, calories start to factor in with beer. In my opinion, any vodka based canned drink, hard seltzers, etc, are going to be the safest drinks from a health standpoint. The real bottom line is if you value your looks quit now. Once drinking and drugging turns into a science experiment where you know all this shit, it's already gone too far.

Look at all the anons lately who are showing off their Explorer I's.

You're talking about prestige. I'm talking about intrinsic quality.
The most basic 7k€ steel Datejust has literally the same 3235 movement as a full gold 40k€ Submariner Date. It's also made with the same level of finishing in the same factories. And yet you still misunderstand.
>Fashion is undeniably for women and homosexuals
Clearly not. It's for everyone, It's a HOBBY. Hobbies aren't restricted to specific groups and all groups and subgroups are able to enjoy that specific hobby.
>you bet your sweet ass if men could pull tail while dressing like slobs none of them would bother with fashion
Like you said, not many would care about their appearance. And you're only furthering my point that fashion is a hobby. The only reason people would dress fashionably is to impress themselves or those who are "in the know" about whatever pieces you decide to wear. There's a clear distinction between "dressing nicely" and "dressing fashionably": Anyone can dress nicely. They can throw on a dress shirt, some chinos or whatever, and the majority of people would say they're dressed well or nicely. Compare that to people who enjoy fashion as a hobby and can deliberately understand the quality of their outfit and other factors such as matching. From the perspective of the average person who doesn't care, they might look nice, but to someone interested in fashion or clothing would be able to point out many flaws, things like silhouette, fit etc.

It's like saying "all people who cook food are cooks", or "all people who use technology are tech-savvy." It's just not true

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17389801
When it comes to fashion what I observed is that trends tend to follow in an opposite stance. You can see it more clearly with cuts. Not long ago, slim and skinny jeans were the established trend, but now there's a resurgence of straight and baggier cuts. Basically you can predict the following trend by observing the current and assuming it'll be the opposite or a direct clash with it.
The thing is that in the age of social media and terminally online people I doubt we'll see trends surging organically. Subcultures, as a whole, including as a concept are dead save for a bunch of performative revivalists and everything is settled from top to bottom.
In this respect I'm not sure trends will matter as much for the discerning person since they're gonna be completely corporate dictated, which you could argue they always were and you wouldn't be 100% wrong.
But anyway, all of this is just theoretical, I just like to talk about such things. My style is pretty normal and most people wouldn't know I care about fashion just by looking at me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17385287
There's no way around looking like an edgy larper when wearing milsurp, only ways of mitigating it.

Some camouflages will hold a heavier connotation than others, multicam and to a lesser extent flecktarn will have people wondering whether or not to go to school tomorrow around you, whilst patterns like strichtarn, Swedish splinter, and desert night camo aren't as obviously militant. Whilst retired camouflages such M81 woodland have already penetrated the fashion industry for decades, making them much more publicly acceptable among normies. Solid coloured milsurp like OG-107 kit, Austrian brown gray, and glorious west german feldgrau will be much more reliable if that's your concern.

Military sizes run LARGE, they're often made to accommodate layers, liners, and have enough room for flexibility in combat. Sizing down could make your fits more fashionable. The one piece rule is a good one for camo, but shouldn't rule out combinations between certain tops, trousers, boots and accessories in a case to case basis.

Pairing milsurp with certain colours and pieces of civilian clothing will balance out your fit. A flecktarn jacket will look like more of an accessory with a pair of converse and grey pleated trousers, than with a pair of tall leather boots and black cargo pants. Blousing your boots is also a very aggressive statement, do it with heavy consideration.

If you have some skills with a seamripper and perhaps a sewing machine, one of the best ways to make your milsurp truly civilian attire is removing its military components, cut off all nametag and branch velcro, epaulettes, rank tabs, shoulder pockets, cargo pockets on bottoms, and even converting parka length tops to jacket length will heavily reduce an article of milsurps military connotations. Doing so will run the risk of damaging your clothing, and with the nature of milsurp, fabrics underneath certain components may be less faded than fabric directly exposed, resulting in irregularities.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17385308
simple and correct. to add, try not to wear rank/squad/unit/division emblems, logos, numbers, or insignia, as you'll still look larpy even if you follow the one piece rule. and you will very likely be called out if it's for a local active unit

posts.com: Any advice on how to style this jacket I thrifted

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Bump

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17390523
black jeans/chinos/whatever, white leather sneakers (preferably low top) w/ white socks ofc, white top like a plain white tee or sweater underneath depending on the weather. monochrome is a safe bet bc it's hard to mess that up, even tho it's a tad boring. white cap if u feel like it.

maybe some accessories like a silver-colored ring or two, maybe a bracelet of w/e color matches ur skin tone, a silver-colored timepiece or even a simple casio watch would go well w/ this. instead of a cap, u could wear black shades if it's sunny out.

no more than that tho; u wanna keep it simple, especially if u're new to fashion. the more elements u add into ur fit, the more room for error there is. remember: less is more. also it's important that the proportions and silhouette of each piece goes well w/ the rest of the fit.

to get a feel for how other /fa/gs style their pieces, browse the waywt thread, a recurring thread, and read the replies to the fit pics to read the feedback. my style improved a lot in a few years just from doing that (and posting my fits there and listening to feedback, ofc).

I always wanted a Bergmütze hat like this. I have an ushanka for the cold weather, and it's great, but it's a one-season hat. I thought the Bergmütze, being wool, would be great for spring/fall, not too hot and rain resistant, while allowing me to fold down the flaps to give sun protection to the side of my face and my neck.
I finally saw one in person when I was vacationing in Germany this year (I live in the US), and was exactly what I wanted. Not too tall in the front, unadorned, nice shade of green. But they look absolutely preposterous with the flaps down, goofy like you wouldn't believe. It was then that I realized that not once had I ever seen one with the flaps down, it was always touted as a selling point of the design and then skipped over without a demonstration. I couldn't even find people on Youtube praising the hat that would actually show off the fit with the flaps down.
Massive disappointment. Like my dream hat was just fool's gold dipped in snake oil.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>17385415
Boots, buckle and hat are your staples.

You're gonna want at least 2 pairs boots, one for work and the other for going out. Go to your loacal western shop and try on boots, you may have to size down a whole size for example if your sneaker size is 9.5 then you most likely will be a 8.5 in western boots. Your boot fit should feel snug but not constricting, the general rule is your heel should be able to lift about a 1/4in inside the boot. Also keep in mind its gonna take a while to brake in the leather. Expect to pay 200 at least for boots. Here are some brands Ariat, Dan post, Hondo, Double H.

You can find buckles on ebay, there are a ton of unique buckles from the 1970s for a good price check it out.

Hats can be pretty expensive so make sure you find something that you like and fits your face. This is one of those things where you are going to have to go to the store and actually try it out. My general recomendation would be to try out the Stetson "Open Road ", most people seem to be able to pull off the look with that hat and its pretty versitile.

Just a note if you do go ahead and wear this shit in the city, you're gonna stick out and people are gonna make comments. I personally have not gotten negative comments but a bunch of people stare. Confidence is key.

last note being a spic helps

posts.com:
CPUs for the meeting, reflected in the window of a Soho specialist in mod paraphernalia, are a fresh Fruit T-shirt, her black Buzz Rickson's MA-1, anonymous black skirt from a Tulsa thrift, the black leggings she'd worn for Pilates, black Harajuku schoolgirl shoes. Her purse-analog is an envelope of black East German laminate, purchased on eBay if not actual Stasi-issue then well in the ballpark.

She sees her own gray eyes, pale in the glass, and beyond them Ben Sherman shirts and fishtail parkas, cufflinks in the form of the RAF roundel that marked the wings of Spitfires.

CPUs. Cayce Pollard Units. That's what Damien calls the clothing she wears. CPUs are either black, white, or gray, and ideally seem to have come into this world without human intervention.

What people take for relentless minimalism is a side effect of too much exposure to the reactor-cores of fashion. This has resulted in a remorseless paring-down of what she can and will wear. She is, literally, allergic to fashion. She can only tolerate things that could have been worn, to a general lack of comment, during any year between 1945 and 2000. She’s a design-free zone, a one-woman school of anti whose very austerity periodically threatens to spawn its own cult.

>>17378640
I spent years trying to find the perfect pair of jeans. I always wrote off japanese selvedge as being stiff as fuck and overpriced. A couple years ago, I walked into Self Edge in Portland and tried on a few pairs and immediately could understand the amount of detail and quality the japanese put into making denim. I took a risk and bought a pair of heavy weight (21 oz) Iron Heart 888s in their overdyed black and have worn them almost daily for the last year and a half. Iron Heart's denim is notorious for having a really immaculate, dense weave, which results in a heavy yet smooth pair of jeans once you break them in. I know I am a little fanboy for Iron Heart in general, but the quality offered by japanese denim in general regardless of what company you decide to go for is like nothing else. I legitimately have no desire to wear any other pair of pants and have since downsized my wardrobe significantly.

People seem to always get tripped up by paying $300+ for a pair of jeans. Once you take that next step, you arguably pay just as much in the long run than if you were to buy any mass produced denim since the pairs of levis are going to immediately get blowouts in the crotch and high friction/tension areas within 1 to 1.5 years with regular wear, whereas you MIGHT get blowouts with one good pair of heavy weight selvedge in that same time frame. Thats not even considering that japanese denim is dyed with natural indigo and produces much more vibrant and beautiful fade contrast once you start breaking them in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17379429
Nice! I’m guessing you went with momotaros? Before they ship those out, I would strongly advise that you make sure the Jean dimensions are going to fit you. Get one of your best fitting pairs of pants and check the dimensions, especially the waist. Selvedge always has more length than necessary and you will end up cuffing the ankles. The rule of thumb I go by is being able to fit my flat palm in the waist band because the first wash will likely result in some shrinkage. These higher end selvedge companies are usually very helpful with any questions you may have about sizing and washing, so definitely reach out to them with questions.

Once you get them, they will be stiff as fuck. This is because companies use starch to preserve the jeans before they are sold. Wear your jeans every day for months, wash once every 3-4 weeks, hang dry, and trust the break in process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17379117
just got a pair of momotaro jeans, (not the exact ones in your pic but the same brand) and they're already my favorite pair of pants. once they're worn in, they fit like nothing else and the fades after a few months of wearing and your first wash is admittedly pretty cool. they're heavy duty and will last forever if you take care of them. momotaro in particular have tons of really cool "features" that make them fun to wear like the pink inseam stitching, the pockets are lined with a cool print and the buttons have cute details on them. uniqlo has some not bad options for the price if you want to dip your toes into it before dropping $200+ on a good pair of japanese denim. don't worry about bleeding into your other clothes. start with around a 14oz pair and a regular cut, then you can explore other cuts and weights if you like them. they are stiff when you first get them but people overstate how bad it is and how long it takes to break them in. just wear them like you would any other pants; get some work done in them, sweat in them and in a week or two they'll be noticeably comfortable. when you wash them for the first time, ideally after a few months and when they start smelling bad, turn them inside out and wash them by themselves then hang dry. that's it.

posts.com:
>>17379895
The taper occurs from the knee down to the ankle. Relaxed fits usually have slightly more room in the thigh and crotch region, along with a slightly higher rise in some cases. Straight fits are the gray area between relaxed tapered and slim tapered.

>>17380006
Honestly if you keep buying shitty quality fast fashion denim from department stores only to find out that they aren't offering the traditional mid to high rise relaxed/straight fit with the optional taper anymore and are catering to whatever new trends come and go, the logical conclusion to your dilemma is to invest a little more money in buying some selvedge denim. There's an entire universe of selvedge denim makers, all of which offer the classic slim, straight, relaxed fits with the standard mid rise, making it easy to find whats right for you. The edge that these companies have is that their denim is usually more durable and wont blow out nearly as soon due to the denser weaves offered from constructing the denim with a shuttle loom, and they pay much more attention to the small little details with the structural integrity of jeans, such as doing double to triple stitching at a minimum and not cutting corners so to speak. A small list of some commonly known selvedge denim names are Momotaro, Sugar Cane, Iron Heart, Naked and Famous, and Samurai. Each of these companies have their own weave patterns and dyeing processes, resulting in differences of texture and fades characteristics

>>17384758
Not him, but straight fit is generally the most "timeless" look for jeans. Yes, slim and skinny fit will come and go every other generation, but generally the straight fit has always had its place in every era. If it wasn't worn by the rock n rollers in the 60s, it was worn by cowboys and rural folk at that same time period. This is however only one advantage that the standard straight fit has over slim/skinny fits. The other main advantage is the mobility that comes with more open room in the crotch and thighs. The original purpose of denim was for utility, so having a skinny fit and not being able to move around without quickly blowing out the crotch of your jeans pretty much defeats that purpose. There are always ways you can incorporate straight fits into your outfit, but slim/skinny jeans are a little more fringe and end up being less versatile fashion-wise.
